page.description: Replaces each occurrence of a string with another.
page.syntax: Output_String as C = STRTRAN(C character,C substring,[C replacement,[N start_pos,[N occurrences[,N every]]]])

argument.name: Output_String
argument.description: The character string produced by the replacement operation.

argument.name: substring
argument.description: The string to find in the Input_String.

argument.name: replacement
argument.description: Optional. Default = "" (NULL). The string that replaces the substring.

argument.name: start_pos
argument.description: Optional. Default = 1. Specifies which (and subsequent) occurrences will be replaced. A value N for the optional Start_Position begins the replacement at the N th occurrence of substring. Numeric

argument.name: occurrences
argument.description: Optional. Default = All. Specifies the maximum number of occurrences of substring to replace with replacement. Numeric

argument.name: every
argument.description: Optional. Default = 1. Specifies the interval between replacements. Numeric

page.discussion: STRTRAN() replaces every occurrence of substring in 'character' with a replacement. NOTE: You can use STRTRAN() with memo fields.
page.example: strtran("The Road Not Traveled", "Traveled", "Paved") -> "The Road Not Paved" strtran("I much prefer cats", "cats", "dogs") -> "I much prefer dogs"

section.description: You can use STRTRAN() to remove a specific substring from anywhere within another string. For example, to index a field containing titles, without the article "The", you might use the following expression:
section.example: strtran(EVENT, "The ", "") -> "Kentucky Derby" if EVENT stores "The Kentucky Derby".

section.description: This then places "Kentucky Derby" near the other events starting with "K" instead of with the events starting with "T". Typically, an article (i.e., "a", "an", or "the") is capitalized only when it occurs at the start of a title. If so, then capitalizing it within the substring causes the function to remove only the first occurrence. You can use a similar expression to remove "A"s and other articles at the start of character values. The following example replaces every second letter "e" in the search string.
section.example: dim string as C string = "this is the number one replacement function" ? stritran(string, "e", "|", 1, 99, 2) = "this is th| number on| replac|ment function"

page.limitations: The substring argument is case sensitive.
